message_1:
A company needs to transport products from its factories to distribution centers. There are four factories and three distribution centers located at different points in a city. The table below shows the capacity of each factory and the demand of each distribution center.

| | Distribution Center 1 | Distribution Center 2 | Distribution Center 3 |
|---|---|---|---|
| Factory 1 | 50 | 70 | 80 |
| Factory 2 | 60 | 40 | 50 |
| Factory 3 | 70 | 60 | 30 |
| Factory 4 | 30 | 50 | 60 |

What is the maximum amount of product that can be transported from the factories to the distribution centers while respecting the capacity of each factory and meeting the demand of each distribution center? Use network flow algorithms to solve this problem.
message_2:
To solve this problem using network flow algorithms, we will create a graph with nodes representing the factories, distribution centers, and two additional nodes: the source (S) and the sink (T). The capacities of the edges between the nodes will represent the maximum amount of product that can be transported.

1. Connect the source node (S) to each factory with an edge representing the capacity of each factory.
2. Connect each factory to each distribution center with an edge representing the capacity of the factory to supply the distribution center.
3. Connect each distribution center to the sink node (T) with an edge representing the demand of each distribution center.

The graph will look like this:

```
S --50--> Factory 1 --50--> Distribution Center 1 --50--> T
       |            |--70--> Distribution Center 2 --70-->|
       |            |--80--> Distribution Center 3 --80-->|
       |                                                   |
       |--60--> Factory 2 --60--> Distribution Center 1 --|
       |            |--40--> Distribution Center 2 --|    |
       |            |--50--> Distribution Center 3 --|    |
       |                                                   |
       |--70--> Factory 3 --70--> Distribution Center 1 --|
       |            |--60--> Distribution Center 2 --|    |
       |            |--30--> Distribution Center 3 --|    |
       |                                                   |
       |--30--> Factory 4 --30--> Distribution Center 1 --|
                    |--50--> Distribution Center 2 --|    |
                    |--60--> Distribution Center 3 --|    |
```

Now, we will use the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm to find the maximum flow in this graph.

1. Initialize all flows to 0.
2. Find an augmenting path from S to T in the residual graph.
3. Update the flow along the augmenting path.
4. Repeat steps 2-3 until no more augmenting paths can be found.

After applying the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm, we find the following flows:

```
S --50--> Factory 1 --50--> Distribution Center 1 --50--> T
       |            |--20--> Distribution Center 2 --20-->|
       |                                                   |
       |--60--> Factory 2 --10--> Distribution Center 1 --|
       |            |--40--> Distribution Center 2 --40-->|
       |            |--10--> Distribution Center 3 --10-->|
       |                                                   |
       |--70--> Factory 3 --0--> Distribution Center 1 --|
       |            |--60--> Distribution Center 2 --60-->|
       |            |--10--> Distribution Center 3 --10-->|
       |                                                   |
       |--30--> Factory 4 --0--> Distribution Center 1 --|
                    |--0--> Distribution Center 2 --|    |
                    |--30--> Distribution Center 3 --30-->|
```

The maximum flow in this graph is the sum of the flows into the sink node (T): 50 + 20 + 10 + 40 + 10 + 60 + 10 + 30 = 230.

Therefore, the maximum amount of product that can be transported from the factories to the distribution centers while respecting the capacity of each factory and meeting the demand of each distribution center is 230.
